events.text: Indian freedom fighter [Mohandas K. Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohandas_K._Gandhi), known for his campaign of [passive resistance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/passive_resistance) in pursuing the independence of India from the British Empire, was released from incarceration in [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad) after serving less than two years of his six-year prison sentence for [sedition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/sedition). The release came on the recommendation of British physicians that Gandhi should be allowed six months convalescence to recover from a serious illness.

events.text: A flash flood inside an underground iron mine [drowned 41 of the 46 miners inside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milford_Mine), after the crew conducted blasting too close to the bottom of Foley Lake near [Crosby, Minnesota](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crosby,_Minnesota).

At 17:30:00 UTC, the [Greenwich Observatory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich) in England, near [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London), began its service of broadcasting regular of broadcasting a [time signal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/time_signal) for the standard of the exact time of day by hour, minute and second as measured at Greenwich. According to a press release from Greenwich, "the last four seconds of the preceding minute will be heard as 'clicks' when the signal is about to be given, representing the 55th, 56th, 57th, 58th and 59th second, and the final click, which will be a little louder than the others" every minute on [shortwave radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/shortwave_radio) to be heard worldwide, with an announcement of the exact time.

The [Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics) closed in [Chamonix, France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamonix,_France). Norway and Finland tied for the [most gold medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics_medal_table) with four each, but Norway won 17 total medals to Finland's 11.

Mexican rebels retreated from their former stronghold of [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz) when federal troops won a crucial victory at [Córdoba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Córdoba,_Veracruz).

*The Show-Off*, a play by American playwright [George Kelly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Kelly_(playwright)), opened on [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) at the [Playhouse Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Playhouse_Theatre_(New_York_City)) for the first of 571 performances.

events.text: The funeral of former U.S. President [Woodrow Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson) was conducted. He was buried in a vault beneath the center aisle of the chapel of the [Washington National Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral), becoming the first, and only, U.S. president to be buried in the District of Columbia.

Demonstrators raised disturbances outside the German embassy in Washington. About 200 taxi drivers walked onto the embassy lawn, and after planting the American flag, saluted it amid cheers and pistol shots. The controversy arose after the German Embassy had refused to offer condolences or to lower flags in honor of the late President Wilson, who had led the U.S. against the German Empire during World War One from 1917 to 1918.

events.text: The first [execution by lethal gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/gas_chamber) in American history was carried out in [Carson City, Nevada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_City,_Nevada) at the [Nevada State Prison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nevada_State_Prison). Chinese national [Gee Jon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gee_Jon), convicted of a gangland slaying, was put to death with a chemical reaction that put [prussic acid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/hydrogen_cyanide) into an airtight chamber.

On the same day, the U.S. state of Texas executed five prisoners— all African-American inmates who had been convicted of murder— at the [state penitentiary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huntsville_Unit) in [Huntsville, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huntsville,_Texas), in the state's first use of the [electric chair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/electric_chair). Starting at 12:09 a.m., Charles Reynolds was the first to die "as Warden Walter Monroe Miller threw the switch which sent 2,500 volts and 11 amperes of electricity into Reynolds's body. Over the next hour, E. L. Morris, George Washington and Mack Matthews were put to death. The fifth inmate, Melvin Johnson, was electrocuted after a one-hour stay of execution.

The [Nakhchivan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) was created by the Soviet Union within the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic. On January 20, 1990, it would become the first part of the Soviet Union to secede.

events.text: German nationalists attacked the headquarters of Rhineland separatists in [Pirmasens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirmasens), smashing their way into the building and setting it ablaze, while snipers outside shot at the separatists. The fighting and the blaze killed 36 people, most of them separatists, an elderly woman bystander was killed by a stray bullet.

The day after testifying in the trial of Shoeless Joe Jackson, former Chicago White Sox outfielder [Oscar "Happy" Felsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Felsch) was arrested for [perjury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/perjury) in testimony given as a rebuttal witness for Jackson. The arrest came after lawyers for the Chicago White Sox produced letters that contradicted Felsch's statements. Felsch posted his own $2,000 bail and was released.

[Howard Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Carter) abruptly suspended work on Tutankhamun's tomb and had it resealed, "owing to the impossible restrictions and discourtesies on the part of the public works department and its antiquity section."
